 One main reason that gas does not fall as fast as it rises, especially after a big run-up like this is that refiners and distributers get squeezed just as badly, if not worse than the rest of us when oil prices go up. The real winners are those who are just straight producers such as Saudi Aramco, Pemex, Petrobras, etc. In the middle are companies such as Exxon Mobile which drills, refines, and sells. It certainly wasn't hurting, but ultimately does better when prices are low and people are buying a lot. The losers are the Sheetzes, WaWa's, and other distributers who can't raise their prices fast enough to keep up with costs. When oil finally does come down, they try to recoup some of their losses and only bring prices down slowly. 
 
 As someone with a tiny car and a 5 mile commute who works for a company that sells mainly to oil producers, I admit feeling guiltily pleased when prices are high. But hey, there are millions of Americans like me who's jobs depend on oil companies doing well.
